sentence: Margot slams her book shut; Father knits his forehead, his eyebrows forming a funny curve and his wrinkle of concentration reappearing at the back of his head, and he buries himself in his book again; Mother starts chatting with Margot; and I get curious and listen too.

A little while later, when he comes across another interesting bit, he tries again: “You have to read this, Mother!” Mother sits on the folding bed, either reading, sewing, knitting or studying, whichever is next on her list.
Back downstairs, everything has to be done quickly, quickly: I comb my hair, put away the potty, shove the bed back in place.
An idea suddenly occurs to her, and she quickly says, so as not to forget, “Anne, remember to…Margot, jot this down…” After a while it’s quiet again.
Mrs. van D. changes shoes and shuffles through the room in her slippers; Mr. van D. too—a veritable Charlie Chaplin.
Father is sitting (with Dickens and the dictionary, of course) on the edge of the sagging, squeaky bed, which doesn’t even have a decent mattress.
The door opens upstairs at eight-twenty, and this is followed by three gentle taps on the floor…Anne’s hot cereal.
No running water, no flushing toilet, no walking around, no noise whatsoever.
He laughs now and then and tries to get Mother to read a passage.
As long as the office staff hasn’t arrived, sounds travel more easily to the warehouse.
“I can manage without them!” Once he starts reading, he doesn’t look up.
“I don’t have the time right now!” He looks disappointed, but then continues to read.
Walk softly!” A sample of what’s said to Father in the bathroom.
I clamber up the stairs to get my doggie dish.
At the stroke of half past eight, he has to be in the living room.
The ideal family scene has now reached its high point.
I want to read or study and Margot does too.
Pim is drawn into the conversation…Nine o’clock.
The clock is striking eight-thirty!
Come here, you can’t run the water anymore.
Two bolsters can be piled on top of each other.
Be quiet, Otto.
Father and Mother ditto.
Margot and Mother are nervous.
Quiet!
All is quiet.
“Shh…Father.
Shh…Pim!
“I don’t need these,” he thinks.
It’s eight-thirty.
Breakfast!
